title: One dead, 24 injured in Sri Lanka fuel protest; curfew imposed
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – One dead and 24 people injured in Sri Lanka’s central town of Rampukkana, hospital sources said, after police fired gunshots to control a violent situation at a protest against fuel shortage.
A police curfew was imposed in Rambukkana to bring the tense situation under control, the police said.
Protests erupted on Tuesday across the country after the government raised the fuel prices sharply to record high amid severe shortage of fuel and long queues near all the filling stations.
“One dead and 24 injured including eight police,” a source at Kegalle Teaching Hospital told Economy Next.
It was the first death in the protests against the government that has prevailed from March 31.
The fuel price hike resulted in the price increase of wheat flour, bread, and transport, which angered the public.
Police Spokesman Nihal Thalduwa said the police fired after protesters started pelting stones at them.’

“Police warned the protesters but they never listened. They damage the public properties. Then the police used tear gas to disperse them. Later the protesters started to attack the police with rocks,” he told media.
“To control the situation, the police fired and some people have been injured. They are now treated at hospital. Some police officials who got injured also are treated at the hospital.”

The latest violence has occurred when Sri Lanka delegation led by Finance Minister Ali Sabry has started talks with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Washington DC for a loan to face the ongoing economic crisis.
Analysts said the violence could possibly delay the IMF deal as the global lender would require stability for any of their programme.
The United States and United Nations raised concerns over the latest violence.
Hanaa Singer-Hamdy, the UN Resident Coordinator for Sri Lanka said she was deeply concerned by reports of harm to protestors in Rambukkana.

“Violence by any party involved hinders the rights of all peaceful protestors. Restricting use of force to the minimum extent necessary is vital to protect citizens and their right to exercise fundamental freedoms,” she tweeted.
Julie Chung, the US Ambassador to Sri Lanka called for a transparent investigation.

“I condemn any violence – whether against protesters or police – and call for restraint & calm from all sides. A full, transparent investigation is essential & the people’s right to peaceful protest must be upheld,” she said in her official twitter feed.(Colombo/April 19/2022)
